content: Does the volume of a frustrum really proportional to the cube of its height ?

I was about to approve when realized aflorado already approved while I was still busy solving it :-)

I solved this today using the cubic formula on 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equation#General_cubic_formula
Anyhow, nice puzzle, with multiple ways to solve.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is good but I was a little confused by the statement's tips. Good job nevertheless

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun concept with multiple feasable methods for solving, also nice to learn a new geometry key-word!

From the givens you can calculate the height and volume of the missing piece of the cone. 

Then just use the proportionality ratio r/h = R/H and the formula for volume of a cone to find that:
H^3 = V * 3/pi * h^2/r^2

where V is the volume of the imagined large cone (beerVol plus missing volume), H is the height of the large cone, h is the height of the missing small cone, and r is bottomRadius.

Output is H - h.
I feel like more people know how to look up the cubic equation than iterative methods. Personally, I used scipy and fsolve. I like it.
this is pretty fun

I really like the puzzle itself, good concept, fun to solve!
Also nice to learn a new geomerty name ^^

But I am conflicted about the statement...
In particular:
"This formula will be needed: V = (1/3) * π * h * (r² + r * R + R²)" 
where new variable names are suddenly introduced.
Is is also not stricltly true...I had success just numerically intergrating the shape by stacking discs, granted the given formula would be more accurate/efficient.

I would consider rephrasing "This formula will be needed:" As something more general e.g. "The volume of conical frustum is:" and maybe also providing explanation for h, r and R.

Also in the "oh. tricky" part I feel like the statement has made an assumption on how the problem will be solved (i.e. find values that satisfy the frustum equality), which is a bit confusing if you have another solution in mind (e.g. approximating the shape of the glass with discs).

I'm not qute sure what would improve that, I also feel it's nice that you have provided some guidance and warnings. Pherhaps making it clearer that these are tips and a possible approach.

Cheers!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Its a nice puzzle and fun to solve. At first a tought I had all variables needed but not quite. Thankfully I notice that the rate wich the top radius incriase is constant.
U was so nice appointing this in the statement and giving some references.

I don't understand why the statements suggests "You cannot solve analytically". 
The radius at the top of the beer is a linear function of the beer height (the unknown we look for). Putting this into the volume formula results a single cubic equation with a single unknown. This has an analytic solution, even if the formula is quite ugly. 
But I agree that a successive approximation approach might be even simpler.

Goal
* Please add "." after "in geometry is called a frustum".

* Please change "This formulas" to "This formula".

Interesting problem. I haven't read your solution code nor tried to solve the puzzle yet, but I imagine I may be able to solve the puzzle by considering a cone that's not truncated, and perhaps similar triangles or something in that direction…

Thanks.
If anyone can think of good tags to add, please tell me.

geometry !
integral ?
beer XD

Thanks :)
(fixed)

Okay, I see what you mean.  I had an AI help me, and I think I might have translated what it said wrong.
So I re-worded.  How is it now?
Thanks !!

Thanks Gaming --
That's great feedback and suggestions.
I did a little re-wording.  How is it now?
What is the cubic equation ?

Good!
I like it, I approve!
Good job :)

I don't think you need integration, or proper 'calculus' to solve this. Cubic equation has a solving formula, someone can apply it (e.g. from the wikipedia page) even without fully understanding why it works.
Just like we use the quadratic formula without proving its correctness every time.
Thanks.  I think I'm going to take this back to "Work in Progress" until I figure this out

No worry, your puzzle is fine as it is. I would approve it after I have actually solved it (which I haven't so far).
I really just suggest to replace the "You cannot..." sentence with something like this: "Analytic solution might be a bit tricky, other (iterative) method might be easier." 
And delete the sentence after the *.

OK good thanks 

For some reason I couldn’t come up with that wording: advanced math is not my strong-suit for sure. Let me know if you have any other suggestions.
